awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The semiotics and social practices of constructing a "proper" Singaporean identity
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed dissertation research investigates how "proper" language identities are enacted in Singapore, a discussion situated within broader sociopolitical discourse of global citizenship and local ways of being. This study treats the practices of a "proper" identity as constitutive of a semiotic package or repertoire - a fluid set of semiotic resources which people must balance to enact appropriate levels of "globalness" and "localness" in Singapore. 

Linguistic practices are investigated through variation in Singapore English (SgE), a complex linguistic repertoire encompassing Singlish, the most local and colloquial English, and Standard Singapore English (SSE), which typically indicates higher education and being extra-local. Twenty Singaporeans will be recruited for ethnographic participant observation and recorded in various conversational contexts ranging from formal interviews to casual social gatherings. Casual settings will elicit the use of Singlish, which most basically differs from SSE via the incorporation of Chinese discourse particles and syntax. Contrastively, SSE is used in formal settings. The varied use of SgE across conversational contexts reveals not only intra-speaker variation but also a speaker's underlying beliefs about language and how it should be used. 

The sociophonetic aspect of this research project focuses on variation in voice onset time (VOT), an acoustic measure used to categorize stop consonants, like the difference between /p/ and /b/. Fifty Singaporeans will participate in a series of speech perception tasks testing how SgE stops are categorically perceived. These tasks will provide a sociophonetic profile of VOT in SgE as well as investigating whether VOT contributes to the perception of a speaker's social identity as an acoustic cue.

By combining qualitative and quantitative methods, this work identifies patterns of variation in the production and perception of SgE, paying attention to processes through which variables and practices come to be associated with global mobility or local rootedness. This study will also contribute to existing SgE documentation in providing a sociophonetic account of VOT. Finally, exploring micro- and macro-variation in SgE sheds light on broader issues of language in globalization, post-colonial sociolinguistics, and New Englishes.

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral dissertation improvement grant supported a graduate student’s scientific training and dissertation fieldwork in Singapore where she investigated how Singaporeans negotiate between being both “properly” local and global as an expression of their social identities. This involved examining the various social practices that Singaporeans engage with as well as looking at the range of their semiotic – as in, meaningful signs – repertoires that continuously shift and change according to their social and identity needs. This project gives special attention to the linguistic practices and variables that have salient social meaning as part of each person’s semiotic repertoire. 

The kinds of language and daily social practices we take up as part of our individual and group community identities can be the result of conscious or subconscious choices. Sociolinguistic and linguistic anthropological research focus on the significance of social meaning(s) that are attached to every single sign, or meaningful variables, which are oftentimes not obvious to the users themselves. In the case of Singapore, one variety – Colloquial Singapore English (CSE) – is more useful in informal and solidarity-building contexts while the other – Standard Singapore English (SSE) – is expected in formal settings. This dichotomy in Singapore’s English varieties are part and parcel of Singaporeans’ daily expressions of being both local and global. This investigation looked closely at how this tension is navigated, as people are not merely evaluated based on how local or how global they are but on how well they crucially balance both local and global aspects as part of their national identities. Someone who only speaks CSE or has never traveled overseas could be perceived as someone too local and old-fashioned. Whereas someone who only speaks English (including utilizing Western English accents) or is unable to communicate with elderly Singaporean generations in dialects (such as various Chinese dialects: Hokkien, Cantonese, etc. or other dialects of Malay and Tamil) are potentially perceived as snooty and elitist. However, if one can effectively balance elements of being both local and global at the same time, then they can be perceived as properly progressive and modern while remaining connected to Singapore’s unique multi-cultural heritage. 

The research analyses utilized a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods drawn from both linguistic anthropology and sociolinguistics. For qualitative analyses, numerous audio and visual recordings were gathered during sociolinguistic interviews and participant observations. These data are useful for discourse analysis – how people speak across different contexts – and metapragmatic discourse analysis – why people speak the way they do. Finally, the analyses of (meta)discourse reveal more deeply seated ideologies not only about language itself, but also their own sociolinguistic identities. A speech perception experiment, testing Singaporeans’ perception of voice onset time – a linguistic measure for how we perceive stop consonants – underwent quantitative analyses in order to see whether minute acoustic variables are useful as cues for the perception of social identity. The combination of qualitative and quantitative methods allows for deeper understanding into how macro-level ideologies about language, nation, and identity trickle down and inform the minute, unconscious, and micro-level variations in language. 

This study takes an interdisciplinary approach, using both sociolinguistic and linguistic anthropological theory and analytical tools to articulate the complex relationship between language, society, and the people that participate in them. Crucially, this project investigates the intersectionality between various social practices, like social peer networks, daily family practices, education and participation in certain educational institutions, and language use among family and friends, as well as between participants and the researcher continually shape not only how Singaporeans themselves articulate their identity but also how they understand and evaluate each other’s “proper” identities. In examining the possible range of people’s semiotic repertoire, we can better understand the potentiality and fluidity involved in creating social meaning, both local and global. This study adds to the existing literature on Singapore and Singapore English in providing a unique sociophonetic perspective focusing on voice onset time. Furthermore, Singapore is a fitting case study for any studies concerned with post-colonial and highly diverse dialect contact regions and communities.

The outcomes of this project have resulted in multiple paper and poster presentations at linguistic and sociolinguistic conferences. A paper titled, Negotiating a “Proper” Singaporean Identity: going past the global and the local, was presented at The Sociolinguistics of Globalization I (Hong Kong, 2015). The Social Perception of Voice Onset Time in Singapore English (poster) was presented at the Acoustical Society of America (Salt Lake City, UT, 2016) and New Ways of Analyzing Variation 45 (Vancouver, 2016). A new poster, How to be linguistically “glocal” in Singapore: the range of a linguistic repertoire, will be presented at the upcoming NWAV 46 (2017).  Numerous portions of this work have also been presented to academic audiences at the researcher’s home institution. (Expected dissertation defense: May 2018)
